content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Could accepting a raise ever result in you
taking home LESS money?
Spoiler: No! But you need to understand how tax brackets really work.

terms.definition: The rate at which your LAST dollar of income is taxed‚Äîthe highest bracket rate that applies to any of your income.
terms.example: If you're in the '22% bracket,' only your income ABOVE $47,150 is taxed at 22%

terms.definition: The AVERAGE rate at which all your income is taxed. Total tax √∑ Total income = your actual overall tax percentage.
LEGAL strategies to minimize your tax liability using deductions, retirement contributions, and tax credits allowed by law.
terms.example: 401(k) contributions, itemizing deductions, timing income recognition

terms.definition: ILLEGAL actions to avoid paying taxes owed‚Äîhiding income, falsifying records, or failing to file returns. A criminal offense.

leftPanel.title: What Many People Believe (Wrong!)
paragraphs: "If I earn more and move into a higher tax bracket, all my income will be taxed at the higher rate, so I might take home LESS money."

highlightBox.text: How It Actually Works: Only the income ABOVE each bracket threshold is taxed at that bracket's rate. Earning more ALWAYS means keeping more!

stats.label: "I'll lose money if I get a raise"
Only new dollars are taxed at higher rates

scenario.name: Jared: Single Filer, $50,000 ‚Äî Understanding His Tax Situation
paragraphs: Jared earns $50,000 as a marketing coordinator. He's offered $5,000 in overtime work. Some coworkers say "it's not worth it‚Äîyou'll just lose it to taxes." But Jared knows better!
His overtime is taxed at his marginal rate (22%), so he'd net about $3,900. That's $3,900 more than he had before‚Äînot a loss!

scenario.name: Sara & Spouse: Married Filing Jointly, $110,000
paragraphs: Sara and her spouse have a combined income of $110,000. Filing jointly gives them access to wider tax brackets‚Äîthe 22% rate doesn't start until $94,300 (vs. $47,150 for single filers).
If Sara (earning $90K) filed separately while her spouse (earning $20K) filed separately, they'd pay MORE total tax. Filing jointly saves them money!

How does understanding the difference between marginal and effective rates change your perspective on earning more money?

Would you turn down a raise because of taxes? How might this affect career decisions?

Is it ethical for individuals and corporations to use every legal strategy to minimize taxes, even if it reduces public funding?

Where is the line between avoidance and evasion? What's your responsibility as a taxpayer?

takeaways.title: Two Different Rates
takeaways.description: Marginal rate = tax on your last dollar; Effective rate = your average rate. They're always different!

takeaways.title: Earning More Always Wins
takeaways.description: Earning more ALWAYS means keeping more. Only the income in each bracket is taxed at that rate.

takeaways.title: Filing Status Matters
takeaways.description: Filing status significantly affects your brackets. Married filing jointly has the widest thresholds.

takeaways.title: Know the Difference
takeaways.description: Tax avoidance is legal and smart. Tax evasion is criminal. Know the difference!

main.title: Analyze Real Cases
main.description: Examine two famous cases‚ÄîAl Capone (convicted of tax evasion) and Amazon's tax strategy (legal avoidance)‚Äîto understand the crucial difference between legal tax minimization and criminal tax evasion. Research {{STATE_NAME}} tax rules at {{STATE_TAX_AUTHORITY_URL}}
